And make sure we've got it because also you got to have things that people use it for and we're very happy where we're sitting at the moment and we'll just review as we go forward.
Thank you.
Richard?

Hey John and Dave. Just looking at the results from your cell phone Octave and if you look at the acceleration or let's say no real broadband growth in the market from fixed line, we still got a continuation in wireless. I am just trying to get a gauge in terms of obviously with ongoing discussions with the government and NBN Co. whether these dynamics which will obviously changing on a day-to-day basis have changed the tone of your conversations since December because obviously we have seen those changes. And with regard to the announcement overnight from Google as well in terms of obviously trailing things in the States, does that change the dynamic as well. So it's interesting to see – hear the commentary in terms of obviously whether the tone is changing?

Our tone hasn't changed. I think we have always been very clear about what we see as the future opportunities and the commercial returns around investor. The Google announcement in the U.S., I mean it is a trial. It's only in the U.S. We have spoken to Google about their intentions. It's an interesting development. Google has opening to put that cable across the Pacific. Now they are going in – locally in the U.S. I think Google is going to continue to be therefore we have many flaccid relationships with Google. That hasn't changed the tone of the discussions? No, no. We are very clear about what we think is the future take-up rights and opportunities. John, do you want to -?
No, I think you're absolutely right.
Okay. Thanks.

Thanks . Dave and John, related to the NBN, we have obviously got the consumer and competition safeguards built which might be reintroduced the senate from the – I think the 22nd of February, what are you expecting in terms of that. Are you expecting to be a modified build from what we saw in November?
I do not know the answer to that. John?
No, I'm sorry. We – .
you are hoping to see in terms of that, especially the first half of the build, which obviously has the ability to start triggering functional separation with the timeframe.
Yes. But we continue to work with the government on all these aspects and where – we will see where it goes to.
Okay. Thank you.
I think we have one final question from the phone line, is Christian there?
Thank you. So we have Christian Guerra from Goldman Sachs.

Hi. I have got a follow-up question. It just relates to the pricing changes you put through both on fixed line broadband and wireless broadband. I guess the key to bring the people together was that the price changes you put through the fixed line broadband at the end of November were – what I would call fairly cosmetic whereas the changes you put through on wireless broadband were probably most significant we've seen from the company' in sometime. So, could you please just talk through your strategy there is question number one.
And question number two, have you seen any noticeable reduction in chain or customer growth across both of those products since the changes. Thanks.

Okay. Well, it's only about strategy has not changed. We still want to come out of the premium because we think the proposition of faster speed and better coverage is with premium. However, it's about what premium you can sell and if the market gets its way on you you see I can't justify 30, 40, 50% premium. So we must remain – able to truly quantify our pricing position. Well, as well as we move prices because we've got our own growing – 1.3 million wireless broadband customers. And so you understand the impacts as you put price in the market, and you've got people who re-contract and so you look at that impact, but Christian you should take off of that announcement.

We must remain competitive and share is important to us. And then, but we got to balance that. Well, we've got a little bit of margin though as well as I'm going to give you EBITDA growth and therefore there is true growth, that's what will drive us.

If we're doing it at an EBITDA, perhaps that EBITDA is going to get down that's not a good strategy, so that's the balance where we continue to work with. We've been pleased with the response so far and it's definitely had an impact and I'm just looking running that business and I am sure it's just a little bit too early to really declare great victory, but we're seeing some early signs of that is coming back at both, but we will keep you posted on that.

But look we must continue to work with our customers, got a good customer service, good offers, people care about those things. And by the way, I should mention customer service does relate to processing strategy too. Customers – if you are too expensive and I fear and I've been very low I say, why should I stay . So you've got to really balance this out going forward. And the market has moved significantly and we must remain competitive.
Okay.
Thank you. We have no more questions. And if David wants to make any just closing comments and we will close that.

Yeah. Thanks, Ben. Look it has been a challenging six months. We did not expect the decline in the usage on PSTN. However, we are going to take action to continue to be competitive and drive this business forward, we must and we will do what's necessary going forward. Thanks mate.
Thank you.
Thank you
